results.title: Under the Clock cinema slide

This hand coloured slide is an advertisement for the film ‘Under the Clock’ featuring Judy Garland by Metro Goldwyn Mayer Ltd. A piece of light brown tape has been adhered to the top edge of the image to cover session times.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

This film, titled ‘Arnhem Land’, contains scenes from a trip to Arnhem Land and Katherine in the Northern Territory in the 1970s.

Travel is by jeep on dusty roads, boats and walking. Wallace captures the varied landscapes of rivers, rocky outcrops, hills, trees, flowers and the scrub as well as termite mounds. He also films buffalo, lizards and waterbirds. A highlight is the Aboriginal rock art drawings throughout the film.

Originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 titles ‘WHC Presents’ and ‘Arnhem Land Safari’
00:01:08:00 sign for the township of Katherine in the Northern Territory.
00:02:05:00 truck travels along a dirt road with scrub burning-off on either side.
00:02:29:00 truck travelling crossing a river.
00:02:48:00 pictorial map of the Jim Jim Falls area.
00:03:28:00 canvas tents at a campsite.
00:06:55:00 four wheel drive and trailer.
00:07:52:00 water buffalo.
00:08:00:00 very large bird in equally large nest at the top of a tree.
00:14:30:00 sign ‘Northern Territory Administration Aboriginal Reserve’.
00:13:45:00 examples of Aboriginal rock art drawings which appear until the end of the reel.
00:24:50:00 swimsuits of the era while swimming in a river.
00:27:00:00 digging a tourist bus out of a sandy track.
00:28:58:00 skeletal remains in the mouth of a cave.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker during the 1960s to the 1990s. Wallace was particularly keen on capturing both the Australian landscape and the people who enjoyed it. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke.

In this film, the filmmaker shows life on and around the beach at Anglesea in Victoria - walking, hang gliding, surfing, motoring in the dunes and on the sand, taking in the views from the cliffs. Wallace focuses on examples of coastal wildflowers as well as animal life where he finds it.

Originally made using Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:06:46:00 hikers in the dunes.
00:11:00:00 a large snake in a tree.
00:11:25:00 hang gliding off the cliffs.
00:13:28:00 walkers on the beach.
00:15:23:00 a crab in the shallows.
00:16:04:00 surfing.
00:18:54:00 a jeep pulling a stuck ‘Holden’ station wagon car from the sand.
00:19:30:00 women looking over the view from the dunes.
00:19:54:00 a ‘jeep’ vehicle charging up a steep dune track.

results.title: Kyneton: queen of the uplands
results.brief_description: Promotional film about Kyneton, Victoria, the ‘Cinderella of Victoria’s summer resorts’. Scenes include: the railway; civic buildings; a hotel; shops; churches; the racecourse; botanical gardens; a golf course; a high school and shots of the town taken from the balcony of Rock House. Local points of interest shown include: views from Rockview Ridge and Ennis Hill; Panorama Rocks; Mitchell’s, Quigg’s and Turpin’s Falls; Lincoln Knitting Mills; mineral springs; Metcalf Cascades; the Campaspe and Coliban Rivers; Coliban Reservoir at Tylden and the homestead of Gerald Buckley’s horse stud. Kyneton Agricultural Show is featured.

results.title: [The White continent]
results.brief_description: In late 1949, a joint expedition planned by the Governments of Britain, Norway and Sweden left for Queen Maude Land on the Antarctic continent - this was to be the first truly international expedition to the Antarctic. The film covers the first stage of the journey, from departure point in Europe to the establishment of the base camps and later withdrawal of the ship’s party, leaving the groups of scientists to their study of the unknown world of ice and snow. Photography by Tom Stobart.

results.title: Venezuela
results.brief_description: Although rich in oil, Venezuela is beset with staggering problems. Poverty is rife in its capital - Caracas - where thousands of Indians dwell in one-roomed ranchitos. At the opposite pole are the rich with virtually no middle class between the two. The region of Orinoco seems immune to improvement and overall continued development in Venezuela depends largely on increased efforts in the areas of education and economic reform.

holdings.name: 16mm film; Access Print (Section 1)

results.title: The Gunpowder Man
results.creator_credit: John Richardson and Eastern Suburb's Children's Film Group
results.brief_description:
In this short film, made in 1966, two children build a Guy Fawkes statue, but are spotted by a third child who reveals their secret to their classmates. The children fight over the statue and eventually join forces to light the bonfire together.

The burning of a Guy Fawkes effigy is a tradition that emerged in the UK, initially to commemorate the failure of a plot, known as the Gunpowder Plot, to assassinate King James I in London on 5 November 1605. In its modern form, the tradition is celebrated as more of a social gathering, with a display of bonfires and fireworks. In Australia, it has become less common since the 1970s.

This short film was sponsored by the Eastern Suburbs Children’s Film Group, Melbourne, and produced and directed by John Richardson. Written by John Richardson and Val Fairweather. Featured cast include Christopher Wilson, Scott McClung, Christopher Ely, Robert Bartnik, Ian Mathieson, Daniel Meltzer, Stephen Palamountain and Jamie Steuart.

results.title: The Bedspread
results.creator_credit: Natalie Green, Elizabeth O'Neill and Berry St Film Productions
results.brief_description: Concerns two poverty-stricken women, Mrs Clancy and Mrs Parsons, living in Melbourne during the depression. Mrs Clancy owns a good bedspread, her pride and joy. Mrs Parsons asks to borrow the bedspread in preparation for a visit by a specialist to her sick daughter. This small incident becomes the focal point of the day. Cast includes Janet Robertson, Moira Claux and Kim Deacon. Based on a short story by Iris Simmons.
